definition: to accuse wrongly/to treat unjustly/injustice/wronged/not worthwhile
injustice/grievance/wrong
to twist/crooked/unjust/in vain
pointless trip/not worth the trip
wasted money/pointless expense

sentences.english: Would you extend apologies to those you may have wronged or hurt?
sentences.chinese: 你會向那些你冤枉過傷害過的人道歉嗎？

sentences.english: Learn from the experience of others, it is less costly mistakes fastest shortcut.
sentences.chinese: 學習他人的經驗，是少走冤枉路的最快捷徑。

sentences.english: Assuming you are prepared to spend money wasted.
To ChengRuShan TangZheng with his guarantee that it is wronged.
sentences.chinese: 唐正對程如山用自己的保證這事是被冤枉的。

sentences.english: I did him a great wrong by calling him a liar.
sentences.chinese: 我說他是個大騙子，這大大地冤枉了他。

sentences.english: These road signs make sure that tourists don't go the wrong way.
sentences.chinese: 這些路牌可以防止遊人走冤枉路。

sentences.english: "You wrong yourself in this, " said Hester gently.
sentences.chinese: “你在這一點上冤枉了自己，”海絲特溫和地說。

sentences.english: She has wronged me, and I wish to do her justice.
sentences.chinese: 雖然她冤枉了我，可我還是希望對她做到仁至義盡。

sentences.english: I’d love to hear about your experiences with feeling wronged.
sentences.chinese: 我想聽一聽當你們被冤枉時的感覺。

sentences.english: Journal Zhenghun by my cousin, wronged a lot of money, but to no avail.
sentences.chinese: 我表哥通過雜誌徵婚，冤枉錢花了不少，卻沒有成效。

sentences.english: The food police may find this hard to take, but chocolate has gotten a bad rap.
sentences.chinese: 不管食物警察愛不愛聽，巧克力真是冤枉的。

sentences.english: She acted out the role of wronged lover.
sentences.chinese: 她扮着一個受冤枉的情人。

sentences.english: We went the long way, thanks to your rotten idea.
sentences.chinese: 由於你的餿主意，我們跑了不少冤枉路。

sentences.english: In the struggle against enemies, we should avoid wronging an innocent person.
sentences.chinese: 在對敵鬥爭中，我們要避免冤枉好人。

sentences.english: Wrong word to the agricultural explained, and I'm sorry.
sentences.chinese: 冤枉的道向農解釋了，並且抱歉。

definition: old variant of 冤[yuan1]
guilty and deserves to be punished (idiom); entirely appropriate chastisement/the punishment fits the crime
death cannot wipe out the crimes (idiom); dreadful crimes that rankled even after the perpetrator is dead
to complain of an injustice/to lament sb's misfortune
to entrap/to frame/to plant false evidence against sb
variant of 污衊|污蔑[wu1 mie4]
to blame sb wrongly
to use public office to avenge private wrongs
to cry out a grievance
to accuse falsely
to kill/to cause death/to do sb to death
to involve/to implicate sb/to spread to others (harm, trouble, damage etc)
to have only oneself to blame (idiom)/to bring trouble through one's own actions
to receive unjust treatment/injustice
to entrap/to set up/to frame (up)/to make false charges against
guilty of terrible crimes (idiom)/reprehensible
